note:
I met my Linzy here and she probably would have stayed in Lijang forever if it wasn't for love and to be honest I wouldn't have blamed her.

A place you can be very happy.

If you have the good fortune to be here, escape the city. Head to Dali or Lijang or Shangri La and see the world at its most content.

snippets.text: Jetlagged, I tell Linzy I need a coffee. She takes me to what used to be an abattoir – an interesting place called 1933 Old Millfun. Now it's a trendy mall. The only cafe appears to have dogs – some kind of puppy cafe. I notice one of the dogs is actually a pig and
snippets.title: Surprising Shanghai – drinks in books and pigs in cafes

snippets.text: It is impossible to mention Erhai [洱海] without first emphasising that Cangshan [苍山] is a long stretch of snow-capped mountain parallel to it. With 19 peaks and elevation between 3,500m to 4,000m above sea-level, Cangshan [苍山] is quite impossible for an average human to conquer. Most often, travellers would resort to taking aerial tram rides
snippets.title: The inseparable Cangshan Erhai [苍山洱海]

snippets.text: Duration: about 1 hour View from the train window: we probably went from 1,500m to 1,900m above sea-level without feeling much difference in the train. The sky was so blue and the fields were lined with crops.
snippets.title: Train Journey: Chuxiong [楚雄] to Dali [大理]

snippets.text: The cafe owners in the ancient town work extremely hard over the various Chinese public holidays because that's when most Chinese people travel to Dali. With all the income made from these peak seasons, it is enough to cover costs for the entire year. And that's enough for them, anything extra is a bonus.
snippets.title: Dali Ancient Town [大理古镇]
Kunming is the gateway to Western China. The pace of life is slow here. The world is somehow more beautiful and real. Here your English doesn't get you far.

snippets.text: Back in November 2014, there were quite limited options to getting around, we took a long-distance coach from Kunming [昆明] to Yuanmou [元谋] and stayed the night at Xinhua Village [新华乡] that is closest to the earth forest. There is really nothing much to do around here except taking a walk around the nearby village,
snippets.title: Langbapu Earth Forest [浪巴铺土林] – the beginning of everything

snippets.text: What do you do when your city is under shelter-in-place order? Grow emergency bean sprouts?Attempt to draw?Spread positivity in the neighbourhood? Been there, done that? How about, jumping into the past? Click onto a random folder of old travel images and let your memory run, backwards. It was the summer of 2015. Jon came to
snippets.title: The Mount Mogan Green [I]

snippets.text: As we descended from the villa, we followed the true residents of Mount Mogan, who kindly led us to the waterfall. That was years before we knew about iNaturalist – a time where a beetle is a beetle (to us), with no name of its genus or subspecies. I knew Jon is a lover of
snippets.title: The Mount Mogan Green [II]

snippets.text: Xizhou [喜洲] – literally Happy [喜] Continent [洲] in Chinese – is a little town in Dali [大理] located on the west of Erhai [洱海] and 29km away from Dali Ancient Town [大理古镇]. In her heyday, it served as an important trading post along the Chama Gudao [茶马古道] – literally Tea [茶] Horse [马] Ancient
snippets.title: Xizhou [喜洲] – our happy place

snippets.text: Yunnan [云南] – literally Cloud [云] South [南] in Chinese – is a region in western China with the most spectacular terrains. At an average of 2,000m above sea level, locals believe that this is the closest anyone could get to the skies. It is good to know the elevation of these major places before planning a trip so
snippets.title: Yunnan [云南]

snippets.text: "Tibet seemed too vast and inaccessible and strange for anyone to possess it. It looked wonderful to me, like the last place on Earth; like a polar ice cap, but emptier."
snippets.src: "Tibet seemed too vast and inaccessible and strange for anyone to possess it. It looked wonderful to me, like the last place on Earth; like a polar ice cap, but emptier."
snippets.title: Quote

snippets.text: I always imagined I first trip would be touching down in Beijing and checking out The Great Wall. Instead I found myself extremely bored in Hong Kong (a week there is far too long) and taking a day tour (I hate tours) to China to Guangzhou.It wasn't as glamorous as my travels with Linzy in
snippets.title: I went to Mainland China from Hong Kong and all I got was a photo of myself on a panda plate

snippets.text: I went to China on a tour as I had no choice as I had no visa and this was the only way to get in the country from Hong Kong.  I hate tours, and this I think is good justification to why. They wanted £10 for a photo of me eating food in a rubbish Chinese restaurant with pandas around me. For all I know the Chinese writing at the top reads "mug". <small>[image from Flickr]</small>
snippets.title: I went to China and all I got was this lousy panda plate

snippets.text: Chuxiong [楚雄] was an impromptu stop along the way before we made our way to Dali [大理] and we had the most unexpected experiences… It is the simplest of town with not many tourists and we spent the day doing what the locals do. We enjoyed watching the Yi people, dressed in their traditional costumes,
snippets.title: Chuxiong [楚雄]
